facts.text: Appeal under Article 132 of the Constitution of India against the judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta in Criminal Miscellaneous Case No. 361 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Art. 132  1  of the Constitution of India, against the judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta in Criminal Miscellaneous Case No. 361 of 1050. C. Gupta and Sudhansu Sekhar Mukherjee  Arun Kumar Dutta and S.N. Mukherjee, with them  for the appellants.

facts.text: Detention orders under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950 served on the appellants on 26th February 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The detention orders under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950, in all cases were served on the appellants on the 26th February, 1950, and the grounds for the detention were served on the 14th March, 1950.

facts.text: Grounds for detention served on appellants on 14th March 1950.

anchor.surface_text: 1950, and the grounds for the detention were served on the 14th March, 1950. By way of specimen we quote one of them You are beings detained in pursuance of a detention order made under sub-clause  ii  of clause  a  of subsection  1 of section a of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950,  Act IV of 1950 , on the following grounds-

facts.text: Appellants assisted operations of Communist Party of India declared unlawful under section 16 of Indian Criminal Law Amendment Act 1908.

anchor.surface_text: That you have been assisting the operations of the Communist Party of India, which along with its volunteer organisations has been declared unlawful by Government under section 16 of the Indian Criminal Law Amendment Act  Act XIV of 1908 , and which has for its object companymission of rioting with deadly weapons, robbery, dacoity, arson and murder and possession and use of arms and ammunitions and explosives and thus acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order

facts.text: Appellant as member of CPI Kishan front fomented trouble amongst peasants of Howrah District and incited to lawlessness and violence.

anchor.surface_text: That as a member of the C.P.I. on its Kishan front, you have fomented trouble amongst the peasants of Howrah District and incited them to acts of lawlessness and vio- lence and have thereby acted in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order

facts.text: Appellant as CPI worker fomented trouble amongst tramways men and workers at Calcutta and incited to violence in speeches at University Hall.

anchor.surface_text: That as a worker of the C.P.I. you have tried to foment trouble amongst the tramways men and other workers at Cal- cutta and in speeches which you delivered at the University Hall and other places you actually incited them to resort to acts of violence and lawlessness

facts.text: Supplementary grounds served on appellants on 16th July 1950 in continuation of grounds of 14th March 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On the 16th of July, 1950, the Government of West Bengal served on the appellants in companytinuation of the grounds already furnished on the 14th of March, 1950, supplementary grounds for their detention a specimen of which is in the following terms--

facts.text: Appellant as Secretary of Bengal Chatkar Mazdoor Union led procession at Howrah on 29th July 1948 preaching discontent against Government.

anchor.surface_text: On the 29th July, 1948, you along with others led a procession at Howrah preaching discontent against Government and have been thus acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Appellants applied for habeas corpus under section 491 CrPC separately.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants applied for a Rule of habeas companypus separate- ly under section 491 of the Criminal Procedure Code and on the 21st July, 1950,

facts.text: High Court issued Rule in each case on Chief Secretary to Government of West Bengal on 21st July 1950.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court issued a Rule in each case on the Chief Secretary to the Government of West Ben- gal. A second set of grounds were companymunicated to the appellants on the 22nd or 23rd of July, 1950.

facts.text: Second set of supplementary grounds communicated to appellants on 22nd or 23rd July 1950.

anchor.surface_text: A second set of grounds were companymunicated to the appellants on the 22nd or 23rd of July, 1950. A specimen of one is in the following terms--

facts.text: Appellant threatened disaster if tram cars taken out on 20th March 1947 in meeting on 19th March 1947.

anchor.surface_text: That in a meeting held at the University Institute on the 19th March, 1947, under the auspices of the Calcutta Tramway Workers Union, you held out the threat that any attempt to take out tram cars on the 20th March, 1947, would be inviting disaster

facts.text: High Court rejected the habeas corpus petitions of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court after companysidering the whole matter re- jected the petitions of the appellants and the appellants have thereupon companye in appeal before us.

facts.text: Preventive Detention Act 1950 passed by Parliament in last week of February 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Preventive Detention Act, 1950, was passed by the Parliament of India in the last week of February, 1950, and these orders on all those detenus were served on the 26th of February, 1950.

facts.text: Large number of persons detained under Bengal Criminal Law Amendment Act 1930, validity challenged in High Court, judgment expected end February 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Bengal Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1930, a very large number of persons were detained. The validity of that Act was being challenged in the High Court and the judgment was expected to be delivered towards the end of February, 1950.

facts.text: Appellants contended that communication of grounds on 14th March 1950 not as soon as may be per Article 22(5).

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court, it was first companytended on behalf of the appellants that the companymunication of the grounds dated the 14th March was number a companypliance with article 22  5 of the Constitution of India, as those grounds were number companymu- nicated as soon as may be.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with High Court that grounds of 14th March 1950 complied with Article 22(5).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected this companytention. Under the circumstances of the case, we agree with the High Court and are unable to hold that in furnish- ing the grounds dated the 14th March, 1950, the authorities had failed to act in accordance with the procedure laid down in article 22  5  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellants contended non-compliance with Article 22(5) and section 7 Preventive Detention Act in supplying grounds.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was next urged that there has been a number-compliance with the procedure laid down in article 22  s of the Constitution and section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act in the manner of supplying grounds to the appellants

facts.text: Supplementary grounds of 16th July 1950 described as continuation and not new grounds by court.

anchor.surface_text: Examining the companytents of the later companymunication in that way we find that they only furnish details of the second heads of the grounds furnished to the appropriate appellant on 14th March, 1950, in respect of his activities. We are unable to treat them as new grounds

facts.text: High Court considered grounds not vague and procedural requirements complied with.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has companysidered the case of each appellant in respect of the companymunication dated the 14th of March, 1950, sent to him. In their opinion those grounds are number vague. They have held that the procedural requirement to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a represen- tation has number been infringed

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: Large number of fresh detention orders made overnight under new Act after local Acts validity in doubt.

anchor.surface_text: One additional point raised in this appeal was that the fact that a large number of fresh orders of detention were made overnight indicates bad faith on the part of the authorities,

issues.text: Whether the communication of the grounds dated the 14th March was a compliance with article 22(5) of the Constitution of India, as those grounds were communicated as soon as may be

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court, it was first contended on behalf of the appellants that the communication of the grounds dated the 14th March was not a compliance with article 22(5) of the Constitution of India, as those grounds were not communicated as soon as may be.

issues.text: Whether there has been a non-compliance with the procedure laid down in article 22(5) of the Constitution and section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act in the manner of supplying grounds to the appellants resulting in not providing the earliest opportunity to make a representation

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was next urged that there has been a non-compliance with the procedure laid down in article 22(5) of the Constitution and section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act in the manner of supplying grounds to the appellants resulting in not providing to the appellants the earliest opportunity to make a representation,

issues.text: Whether the supplementary grounds communicated on 16th July 1950 were new or additional grounds requiring communication as soon as may be under article 22(5), indicating that the original grounds were insufficient

anchor.surface_text: When the authorities sent their second communication dated 16th July, 1950, to the appellants they described it as in continuation of the grounds already furnished and as the supplementary grounds for your detention. Relying on the wording of this communication it was argued that these were additional grounds

issues.text: Whether the grounds of detention were vague such that they could not be considered as grounds at all and were insufficient to satisfy the authorities under section 3 of the Preventive Detention Act

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued that the grounds being vague, they could not be considered as grounds at all and therefore they could not be sufficient to satisfy the authorities. On this point we have nothing to add to what we have stated in our judgment in Case No. 22 of 1950.

issues.text: Whether the procedural requirement under article 22(5) to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a representation has been infringed by the communication of the grounds

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has considered the case of each appellant in respect of the communication dated the 14th of March, 1950, sent to him. In their opinion those grounds are not vague. They have held that the procedural requirement to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a representation has not been infringed

issues.text: Whether the fact that a large number of fresh orders of detention were made overnight indicates bad faith on the part of the authorities

anchor.surface_text: One additional point raised in this appeal was that the fact that a large number of fresh orders of detention were made overnight indicates bad faith on the part of the authorities, for the authorities could not have applied their minds to each individual case.

arguments.claim: Vague grounds are distinguishable from irrelevant grounds and do not vitiate the authority's satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the companytention that vague grounds stand on the same footing as irrelevant grounds. An irrelevant ground has numberconnection at all with the satisfaction of the Provincial Government which makes the order of detention.

anchor.surface_text: Examining the companytents of the later companymunication in that way we find that they only furnish details of the second heads of the grounds furnished to the appropriate appellant on 14th March, 1950, in respect of his activities. We are unable to treat them as new grounds

arguments.court_reasoning: Whole document read, not just opening words; agrees with High Court.

holdings.text: Under the circumstances of the case, we agree with the High Court and are unable to hold that in furnishing the grounds dated the 14th March, 1950, the authorities had failed to act in accordance with the procedure laid down in article 22(5) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Under the circumstances of the case, we agree with the High Court and are unable to hold that in furnishing the grounds dated the 14th March, 1950, the authorities had failed to act in accordance with the procedure laid down in article 22(5) of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sudden need to handle large detentions after challenge to Bengal Act and passage of new Preventive Detention Act justified the timing of communication on 14th March.

holdings.text: A description of the contents of the second communication as supplementary grounds does not necessarily make them additional or new grounds. One has to look at the contents to find out whether they are new grounds... Examining the contents of the later communication in that way we find that they only furnish details of the second heads of the grounds furnished to the appropriate appellant on 14th March, 1950... We are unable to treat them as new grounds.

anchor.surface_text: When the authorities sent their second communication dated 16th July, 1950, to the appellants they described it as in continuation of the grounds already furnished and as the supplementary grounds for your detention. Relying on the wording of this communication it was argued that these were additional grounds

holdings.reasoning_summary: Whole communication must be read; contents provide details of original grounds' second heads, not new grounds; relies on Case No. 22.

holdings.text: The sufficiency of the grounds, which gives rise to the satisfaction of the Provincial Government, is not a matter for examination by the court. The sufficiency of the grounds to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a representation can be examined by the court, but only from that point of view.

anchor.surface_text: The sufficiency of the grounds, which gives rise to the satis- faction of the Provincial Government, is not a matter for examination by the court. The sufficiency of the grounds to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a representation can be examined by the court, but only from that point of view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes subjective satisfaction under s3 PDA (non-justiciable) from sufficiency for representation under Art 22(5) (justiciable); vague grounds not equivalent to irrelevant; relies on Case No. 22.

holdings.text: The High Court has considered the case of each appellant... In their opinion those grounds are not vague. They have held that the procedural requirement to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a representation has not been infringed... After hearing counsel for the appellant we see no reason to differ from the conclusion of the High Court on this point.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has considered the case of each appellant in respect of the communication dated the 14th of March, 1950, sent to him. In their opinion those grounds are not vague. They have held that the procedural requirement to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a represen- tation has not been infringed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court's fact-specific assessment that grounds enable representation; no infringement of Art 22(5).

holdings.text: I am unable to accept this contention as correct. The authorities had already applied their minds to the suspected activities of each of the detenus... There being doubt as to the validity of the local Acts and the Preventive Detention Act having been passed in the meantime... an elaborate application of mind... does not appear to me to be necessary at all.

anchor.surface_text: One additional point raised in this appeal was that the fact that a large number of fresh orders of detention were made overnight indicates bad faith on the part of the authorities, for the authori- ties could not have applied their minds to each individual case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior satisfaction under local Acts carried over to new Act amid validity doubts; no bad faith in bulk fresh orders.

anchor.surface_text: Under the circumstances of the case, we agree with the High Court and are unable to hold that in furnishing the grounds dated the 14th March, 1950, the authorities had failed to act in accordance with the procedure laid down in article 22(5) of the Constitution.
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The sufficiency of the grounds, which gives rise to the satis- faction of the Provincial Government, is not a matter for examination by the court. The sufficiency of the grounds to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a representation can be examined by the court, but only from that point of view.
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has considered the case of each appellant in respect of the communication dated the 14th of March, 1950, sent to him. In their opinion those grounds are not vague. They have held that the procedural requirement to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a represen- tation has not been infringed
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.
